citations.narrative:
The facility has 1 wolf dog hybrid puppy in travel with the exhibit. When asking the licensee, there was currently no
method of identification for this canid. The licensee must use an appropriate method of identification for dogs being used
for regulated activity.
Correct by: January 16, 2024

A female wolf-dog hybrid named "Lakota" had tag 11 and died 1 year ago. At the time of inspection a 1 year old male
wolf-dog hybrid named "Klondike" had tag 11.
Proper identification is required in order to ensure that each animal's identity can be known with certainty and to facilitate
record keeping requirements. The applicant must ensure that no animal identification number is used within any 5-year
period following its previous use.
Correct by January 18, 2024

citations.desc: Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries.
citations.narrative:
The licensee sent a written itinerary for an exhibit at the Georgia State Fair. The licensee did not include the address of
the exhibition event.
The itinerary shall include the following: The names, dates, and locations (with addresses) where the animals will travel,
be housed, and be exhibited.
Include all required information on itineraries for overnight travel. Failure to provide and update itinerary information
results in the Department's inability to conduct an inspection to ensure the welfare of the animals covered under the
Animal Welfare Act.
Correct by January 18, 2024

The licensee has a contingency plan started, but it hasn't been completed. It specifically does not identify the different
types of emergencies that could trigger the need for emergency action to be taken.
Not having a completed contingency plan doesn't help prepare the licensee for if and when an emergency situation may
take place. The licensee must complete a contingency plan in accordance with the requirements outlined in the Animal
Welfare Act.
Correct by January 18, 2024

The licensee did not create and maintain a medical records for 10 wolf-dog hybrids.
Failure to maintain medical records regarding health conditions of the animals and treatments given does not allow APHIS
officials to determine if adequate veterinary care was provided. If a problem is identified (such as a disease, injury, or
illness), the date and description of the problem, examination findings, test results, plan for treatment and care, and
treatment procedures performed must be documented.
Correct by documenting all health conditions and treatments given to ensure that medical records are complete.
Correct from January 09, 2024 onward.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.50(c)(1) 
   
Time and method of identification. 
The facility has 1 wolf dog hybrid puppy in travel with the exhibit. When asking the licensee, there was currently no 
method of identification for this canid. The licensee must use an appropriate method of identification for dogs being used 
for regulated activity. 
 
Correct by: January 16, 2024 
2.55(c) 
   
Removal and disposal of tags. 
A female wolf-dog hybrid named "Lakota" had tag 11 and died 1 year ago. At the time of inspection a 1 year old male 
wolf-dog hybrid named "Klondike" had tag 11.  
 Proper identification is required in order to ensure that each animal's identity can be known with certainty and to facilitate 
record keeping requirements. The applicant must ensure that no animal identification number is used within any 5-year 
period following its previous use. 
Correct by January 18, 2024 
2.126(c)(1)(iii) 
   
Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries. 
The licensee sent a written itinerary for an exhibit at the Georgia State Fair. The licensee did not include the address of 
the exhibition event. 
 
The itinerary shall include the following: The names, dates, and locations (with addresses) where the animals will travel, 
be housed, and be exhibited. 
 
Include all required information on itineraries for overnight travel. Failure to provide and update itinerary information 
results in the Department's inability to conduct an inspection to ensure the welfare of the animals covered under the 
Animal Welfare Act. 
Correct by January 18, 2024

2.134(a)(1) 
   
Contingency planning. 
The licensee has a contingency plan started, but it hasn't been completed. It specifically does not identify the different 
types of emergencies that could trigger the need for emergency action to be taken. 
Not having a completed contingency plan doesn't help prepare the licensee for if and when an emergency situation may 
take place. The licensee must complete a contingency plan in accordance with the requirements outlined in the Animal 
Welfare Act.  
Correct by January 18, 2024 
3.13(b) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The licensee did not create and maintain a medical records for 10 wolf-dog hybrids. 
 
Failure to maintain medical records regarding health conditions of the animals and treatments given does not allow APHIS 
officials to determine if adequate veterinary care was provided. If a problem is identified (such as a disease, injury, or 
illness), the date and description of the problem, examination findings, test results, plan for treatment and care, and 
treatment procedures performed must be documented.  
Correct by documenting all health conditions and treatments given to ensure that medical records are complete.  
Correct from January 09, 2024 onward. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
